title: In English, where will the second form of a verb be used? - Quora

response.answer_text: The second form of verb is generally used when you are talking about past actions, however, this is not correct all the time. For example, the second form will be used in present tense sentences too if it is in passive state. For example: They use this printer a lot. (Active tense simple present sentence)This printer is used a lot. (Same sentence in passive form)

I have looked at a lot of English grammar web sites and books in the USA and have never come across terms like “second form.” I do see the terminology in some Indian sites, like 1st form 2nd form 3rd form of verb, which seem to indicate, as do some of the respondents here, that the second form is the simple past tense. On the other hand, from The Five Verb Forms, one could infer that the “second form” is the infinitive. The complete list there is: base forminfinitive formpast formpresent participlepast participleThose names describe the forms well and are understood by students and grammarians everywhere. I see no need to denote the principal parts of a verb with numbers.
